name: Nagas
abilities: Weather Control: Summon rain, cause drought, create storms or calm waters
Shape-shifting: Transform between serpent, semi-human, and human forms
Treasure Guardianship: Possess and protect vast hoards of jewels and sacred objects
Venom: Deadly poison breath or bite
Longevity: Live for thousands of years, witnessing ages pass
Size Alteration: Shrink to human size or expand to mountain-filling proportions
Water Dominion: Complete control over water in their domain
weaknesses: Mongoose Attacks: Particularly vulnerable to mongoose predators
Iron: Cold iron can harm and repel them
Sacred Insults: Desecration of their sacred waters enrages them
Human Compassion: Can be moved by acts of kindness and redemption
habitat: Underwater palaces in oceans, lakes, rivers, springs, wells, sacred bathing pools
behavior: Protective of waters, guardians of wisdom, can be benevolent or vengeful

christian.overview: The Nagas, as serpent deities of both beneficent and malevolent character, invite comparison with biblical serpent imagery. While the serpent in Genesis represents the deceiver, Christian typology also recognizes the bronze serpent (Numbers 21:9) as a prefiguration of Christ's crucifixion.

biblicalParallels.description: The serpent as tempter contrasts with the Nagas' ambivalent nature; yet both traditions recognize serpents as beings of preternatural wisdom and power.
The bronze serpent (Nehushtan) lifted up to heal Israel prefigures Christ on the cross. This redemptive serpent imagery parallels the protective, healing aspects of beneficent Nagas.
The identification of the serpent with Satan represents the negative pole of serpent symbolism, corresponding to malevolent Naga kings in Buddhist-Hindu tradition.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers developed a sophisticated serpent typology, distinguishing between the deceiving serpent of Eden and the healing serpent of Moses.

sources.author: Justin Martyr
sources.interpretation: The bronze serpent was a type of Christ, who took upon himself the curse of sin (represented by serpent form) to bring healing to those who look upon him in faith.

sources.author: Clement of Alexandria
sources.interpretation: Noted parallels between pagan serpent veneration and the biblical serpent symbolism, seeing in both a distorted memory of primordial truth.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Medieval bestiaries portrayed serpents as embodying prudence (Christ's counsel to be "wise as serpents") alongside their association with temptation.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: The dual nature of serpent symbolism - healing and harming, wisdom and deception - mirrors the Naga's role as both guardian and potential threat.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Christian art sometimes incorporated serpent guardians at sacred thresholds, possibly influenced by ancient Near Eastern and Indian precedents.

christian.typologicalReading: The Nagas' role as treasure guardians and keepers of wisdom finds a transformed echo in Christian understanding of Christ as the one in whom "are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge" (Colossians 2:3).
